description: To provide the public with all relevent information regarding the outbreak, the Surinamese government created a website for public access. The website is accessible by any member of the public, but can only be edited by members of the Corona emergency response team, and associated doctors and researchers.

target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Suriname closed all schools effective March 16th. The plan is to reopen schools the 15th of April. UPDATE: Originally, the Minister of Education announced that schools will reopen on the 15th of April. However, on April 2nd, she announced that they cannot enforce existing policies in schools. As a result, schools remain closed until the policies can be enforced.
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: As of the 11th of May Suriname has instated a nationwide curfew from 23:00 - 05:00. The policy is set to end on the 18th of May. description: As of January 31, 2020, the Ministry of Health of Suriname introduced passenger entry screening. Therefore, the airport and the port, the border posts with neighboring countries, are equipped with scanners and other equipment for testing. The Immigration Service at the Johan Adolf Pengel airport is aware of travelers entering risk areas in Suriname, so these travelers will be questioned and screened extra. Nevertheless, air traffic to and from Europe is still open and there is no negative travel advice yet. They just have adjusted flight schedule to China.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Health Screenings (e.g. temperature checks)
target_geog_level: All countries

description: Traveling between Guyana and Suriname via the so-called Backtrack route was suddenly closed on February 29, 2020 for a seven-day period, following a decision by the Ministry of Public Health of Suriname that was concerned about the threat of the coronavirus.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Total border crossing ban

description: According to the Ministry of Health of Suriname, travelers coming from countries and/or territories where there is a significant COVID-19 outbreak in the past 14 days will not be admitted to Surinamese territory from now on. This scheme applies to both crew members and passengers. As of March 10, 2020, this list of countries consists of: all countries where local transmission is high.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

target_geog_level: All countries

description: Vice President of Suriname, Ashwin Adhin, drew attention to the irregularities at the southern border and the border rivers in the east and west. Therefore, it was announced that government would increase border checks and monitoring at rivers and other water bodies on April 16, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Travel History Form (e.g. documents where traveler has recently been)

description: President of Suriname, Desiré Bouterse, announced tightened COVID-19 measures during his television address on April 29, 2020 which is due to the alarming situation near the eastern border. Also, the closure of the Marowijne, Lawa and Tapanahony rivers will remain until May 10, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Total border crossing ban
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On May 10, 2020, the government of Suriname decided to extend the lockdown on the Lawa, Marowijne and Tapanahony rivers' border rivers until May 17, 2020. However, the total lockdown on these rivers will be converted into a partial lockdown and will last from 6 p.m. to 6 a.m. Also, the borders remain closed. Therefore, crossing to and from our neighboring countries is not possible.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Total border crossing ban
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On June 4, 2020, Suriname has closed all international borders, including ferry services to Guyana. Road and air travel has also been stopped to the eastern part of the country, including the closure of the East-West Connecting Road from Stolkersijver.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Total border crossing ban
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On August 11, 2020, it was announced that Suriname has closed its international borders, including ferry services to Guyana, until at least August 14. However, exceptions are made for medical emergencies, freight operations, and repatriation.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Other External Border Restriction
target_geog_level: All countries

description: President Chandrikapersad Santokhi announced on September 28, 2020, that Suriname will allow direct passenger traffic from the Netherlands while announcing also the resumption of domestic flights in the Dutch-speaking Caribbean Community (CARICOM) country. Also, the head of state said that with regards to the international flights, passengers must submit a negative COVID-19 test and are required to be quarantined for 10 days after arrival. Flights to the interior will be carried out in accordance with the protocols and after screening of Zorg en Hoop Airport.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Negative COVID-19 Test
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Incoming flights from Cuba and Haiti banned as of December 2, 2020 according to the Ministry of Health of Suriname.

description: Commercial flights between Suriname and the Netherlands, as well as highly regulated pre-arranged regional flights, are permitted as of December 7, 2020. Nonetheless, international travel remains highly restricted for most nonresident foreign nationals, and the authorities will determine the number of passengers per flight per week.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Total border crossing ban
target_geog_level: All countries

description: As of December 7, 2020, additional requirements are in place to be permitted entry to Suriname. Travelers must provide a negative PCR test result taken 72-120 hours before departure. They also must provide proof of a confirmed accommodation booking of at least seven days at a registered Suriname Hospitality and Tourism Association (SHATA) hotel or accommodation. Home quarantine is only allowed with written permission from the Ministry of Health. Moreover, nonresidents are required to have travel insurance with COVID-19 coverage.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Health Certificates
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On 16 December 2020 the government of Suriname announced that all international borders remain closed (including the ferry to Guyana).
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

target_geog_level: All countries

description: As of December 22, 2020 in Suriname, all commercial passenger flights are banned from entry, with only cargo flights and specially permitted repatriation flights allowed. The movements of arriving travelers are highly restricted; transport from the airport to accommodations is controlled, and all travelers must complete a mandatory seven-day quarantine.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Total border crossing ban
target_geog_level: All countries

description: As of January 29, 2021, Suriname’s borders are closed to commercial passenger traffic and only passengers authorized by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, International Business and International Cooperation will be admitted on flights to Suriname.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Total border crossing ban
target_geog_level: All countries

description: From Friday 26 March 2021 until Thursday 08 April 2021, the following measures of Suriname's government will remain in force: all borders remain closed for non-essential travels; only returnees with quarantine measures have been admitted. Also, essential passenger traffic is allowed if there is "compliance with the conditions and protocols specific to the country from which the person comes directly; and "after the person has received prior approval from the competent Surinamese authorities to travel, whereby the essential nature of the trip to be made will be assessed." Additionally, domestic flights are only permitted for cargo, repatriation of stranded passengers and for medical emergencies.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Total border crossing ban
target_geog_level: All countries

description: As of April 26, 2021, Suriname’s borders are closed.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

target_geog_level: All countries

description: As of May 6, 2021, Suriname’s borders are still closed.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Total border crossing ban
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
Travelers who are not or not fully vaccinated against the SARS-CoV-2 virus will be allowed to travel abroad from Suriname in the period from May 31, 2021 to June 18, 2021, provided they travel to their country of birth or place of residence or a country of which they are nationals.

Travelers who are fully vaccinated against the SARS-CoV-2 virus will be allowed to travel from Suriname abroad and from abroad to Suriname, only if they: be demonstrably fully vaccinated against the Covid-19 virus (for inbound and outbound passenger traffic); being in possession of a negative SARSCoV-2 RT-PCR test result no more than 72 hours before departure of the flight to Suriname (for inbound passenger traffic) and the traveler is advised to self- or home quarantine seven days after arrival (for inbound passenger traffic).
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: 3G: Must be either (i) vaccinated (ii) have a valid COVID-19 negative test within a certain time frame or (iii) recovered from COVID-19
target_geog_level: All countries

description: From Monday 31 May 2021 to Friday 18 June 2021, only the following flights are permitted in Surinamese airspace: The Netherlands, the Caribbean and the United States of America (outbound and inbound flights for cargo and passenger traffic);  Brazil, Cuba and the Dominican Republic (only inbound and outbound cargo traffic and outbound passenger traffic);  Haiti (no passenger traffic allowed). Additionally, goods and essential passenger traffic by water from Guyana and French Guiana will only be allowed on Wednesdays.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Total border crossing ban
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: As of June 10, 2021, the borders of Suriname are still closed, and commercial flights are not operating. Also, travelers must show a negative PCR test not older than 72 hours and quick test results or antibody test results are not accepted.

description: From the 14th of March in Suriname all the social gatherings or events with more than 100 people are prohibited. From the 27th of March in Suriname all the social gathering or events with more than 100 people are prohibited. UPDATE: The original amount of the maximum amount of people in a social gathering was 100 people. On the 27th of March they changed the maximum amount of people to 10.

description: From the 27th of March until the 26th of April, in Suriname all the social gathering or events with more than 10 people are prohibited. UPDATE: The original Restriction on Social Gathering was set to last until April 12, it has been extended to April 26.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: In Suriname, "all social gatherings or events with more than 100 people were prohibited from March 14 to March 27. In Suriname, from the 27th of March untill the 10th of May all social gatherings or events with more than 10 people were prohibited. From the 10th of May, all social gatherings or events with more than 50 people are prohibited". UPDATE: The original amount of the maximum amount of people in a social gathering was 100 people. On the 27th of March they changed the maximum amount of people to 10. On the 10th of May they changed the maximum amount of people to 50.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
